Reviews.Title: “Very pleased with the Hotel Paba”
Reviews.Author: cnsl
Reviews.Content: We heard about the Hotel Paba through Rick Steve's guide book to Rome. It is located near the Termini train station, the Colusseum, the Forum. After reading the positive reviews on this site and others, we contacted the hotel directly about a triple room. My husband, daughter, and I were thrilled to arrive to find a good size room - the Honeymoon Suite - with a huge bed, and also a single bed. The bathroom may be small by American standards, but it was very functional, and extremely clean. I was excited to have plush towels, and washcloths, having heard how different European towels can be. We stayed 3 nights and were treated wonderfully from the first email contact until we checked out. I would definitely recommend the Hotel Paba to anyone visiting Rome.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel Paba a great place to stay”
Reviews.Author: sharib73
Reviews.Content: Hotel Paba, is an older, smaller hotel, but you can't beat it for the price or the location. It is located in old Rome, literally around the corner from the Coliseum. The rooms are average size for Italy. They were clean and the room was cleaned daily, including bed liens, etc. The bathroom was a nice size as well. Each morning the owner, Alberta, brings breakfast to your room. The breakfast consisted of croissants, rolls, coffee, yogurt, juice, cheeses, etc. You can't beat that especially with the cost of breakfast being included in your room rate. Alberta is a gem! I stayed with my mom and we had a great time. Alberta speaks fluent English and could not have been nicer. She was very patient with our questions. She made reservations for us to eat as well as a day spa where my mother and I got massages. The only negative was the beds were a little on the hard side. But honestly I was so tired after walking all over Rome that I slept like the dead anyway. You also get a discounted rate if you pay for the hotel in euros. I would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “perfect - will stay again - this is how it should be”
Reviews.Author: USAIndytravels
Reviews.Content: Myself and two friends stayed here for 5 nights and found the stay perfectly enjoyable. The room (#6) was large by European standards. It was equipped with three wonderfully firm twn beds. One of us is a "big boy" and the bed was just fine for him. The room had a small refridgerator and wonder little balcony over busy Via Cavour with double pane french doors and closeable shutters. Noise was not a problem. The bathroom was very large and the whole place was spotless. The lovely lady who cares for and runs the hotel was a perfect hostess, always available for advice and help. She brings a lovely little breakfast tray to your room each morning when you arrange time. The neighborhood was just fine. Never felt unsafe at all, even at night. Bus stops directly in front of hotel. Hotel is equidistant to two Metro stops. (By the way, the Rome metro and bus public transport system is wonderful and easy to negotiate to sightsee on your own). In the immediate area is a post office, bank (ATM) newstand (tobacco) store, two small gorceries, a couple of lovely restaurants, travel agent (for train tickets), souvenier shops and of coarse the Colossem and the Forum. Don't miss; St Peter's-in-Chains Church just a block up Via Cavour on the same side. It is a 5 min walk to the Forum/Colossem, 15 mins to San Giovanni in Laterano, 30 mins to the Vatican / Trasterve, 20 mins to Pza. Navonna, Pantheon, 10 mins to Via Nazionale shopping and 5 mins to Cavour or Colosseo Metro stops from the hotel. We personally walked it all! My overall impression of hotel is: cozy, comfortable, clean, safe and excellent price. The service was like family. I will definatly stay here again. I'm hesitant to let you all know, for fear it will become a "secret let out".

Reviews.Title: “No view but a fantastic location”
Reviews.Author: Kelleth
Reviews.Content: We have just returned from a fantastic stay in Rome, and the location of the hotel meant we could walk to every sight we wanted to see. The nearest was the Colosseum and Forum - barely a few minutes walk from your room (as you walk down the Via Cavour to the hotel for the first time you can see the awe inspiring Colosseum to your left as you near the Paba). All the other important piazza's, fountains and churches are around 10-15 mins walk away- although we were sure we could have found shorter routes but the Centro Storico is like a beautiful maze. The furthest we had to walk was to St Peters at 30 mins - we were amazed to find that it was free to walk around the basilica. The hotel was of very good quality for a 2 star - large rooms, high ceilings and well equipped bathrooms. We were disappointed to be given room 3 which was situated behind the reception desk (we heard guests arriving, phones ringing frequently) and which had no view at all but we rarely spent any time in the room. The breakfast was brought to our room but to be honest we only really ate the yoghurts. The croissants were coated in icing sugar (far too sweet for first thing in the morning), there were a few slices of a bizarre toast/biscuit thingy and a few jams and cheese spreads. I am sure it is authentic italian but it was all very indigestible at early morning. I recommend you buy some fruit and keep it in the fridge. It would also be wise to pack a cup/mug in your luggage as none were provided - we drank our tea/coffee in the plastic cups provided which were slightly hot in the hands! Also - we spent the first night using rock hard pillows before finding much softer replacements in the wardrobe. Alberta the owner was extremely helpful though, providing maps and advice - she also let us use the kitchen on our last day as we were leaving before her and the staff arrived for the morning. All in all, the hotel was very good for the money we spent. If you are looking for a base near to all the sights and with excellent facilities considering its rating - Paba is just the hotel for you. Just don't expect a view, its not guaranteed.

Reviews.Title: “not a bad experience”
Reviews.Author: ann_tess
Reviews.Content: we stayed in hotel paba for 4 nights in december. the directions provided were good.the best way to reach is to take the bus (75,84) from outside roma termini and it stops right infront of the hotel.the room was a bit small. but was very clean and had all facilities. the staff was also helpful.there are lot of amenities nearby and all attractions are reachalbe via bus/walk/train. metro stop is also in a walkable distance. the breakfast was poor. in short you get what you pay for and this is defenitely a 2 star accommodation.

Reviews.Title: “small nice comfortable hotel”
Reviews.Author: nastik5
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel at the beging of november. it is very small hotel located on the second floor of the building. it has a small amount of rooms. the room where we stayed was called lover`s nest or something like this. it was a clean, big, nice funitured room. the hotel is situated in a walking ditance to the center. just opposite there is a bakery shop where you can buy all kinds of italian pizza. I liked most of all potato pizza with rosmarine. The lady in the hotel Mrs Castelli is so nice. She has told us the main places to see and how to get there. and also she has advised us a nice small restaurant which was on the next street. The restarant and the food was so good! it was very nice hotel in very reasonable price (for Rome). We stayed also 1 night in anothere hotel, which was more expensive and very poor and not nice.

Reviews.Title: “Great Price, Friendly Staff, Amazing Location”
Reviews.Author: italo1881
Reviews.Content: After discovering this hotel through tripadvisor and noticing all the oustanding reviews, my fiance and I decided to stay at hotel Paba in February 2007. The hotel is located a short walk away (10 mins) from the metro station which is greatly appreciated when you arrive from Milan on a night train, with a couple of luggages. Unfortunately for us, during our trip we didn't have the opportunity to take the historical elevator that everyone is talking about since it was out of order. However, the hotel being on the second floor, it was definetely not too much of an inconvenience. We were greated with a big smile by Alberta at 7 am. She is the personification of a true italian nonna (grandmother). Kind, soft spoken, making sure that you have everything you need (even though you really don't need it ...) The room we had was large and very clean. We paid 88 euros per night and for that price you will not find anything better in Rome. And did I mention the fact that taxes are included as well as breakfast. For those of you complaining about the bread, you need to learn something. Bread in italy is not soft. Its generally hard and I am sure you can break a window if you throw it. Being italian and accustomed to have it, I found the breakfast satisfying. Worst of cases, there is a small breakfast place less then 30 seconds of the hotel, serving fresh pastries... Now, the location. Its just perfect... A lot can be seen in walking distance. Coliseum and the Foro Romano are less then 5 mins walk and the monument to Victor Emmanuel II is less then 10 mins away (you have to see it by night as it is just breathtaking even on a cold February night). The metro takes you everywhere else you want in Rome. Would I recommend this place ??? Evidently !!! But more importantly, would I stay here again next time I am in Rome ??? Without a doubt !!!

Reviews.Title: “Very Pleased”
Reviews.Author: emaurer
Reviews.Content: We were very pleaed with the Hotel Paba. When we booked out stay they were full the first night and reserved a room across the hall at a different hotel in the same building. About 2 weeks before out trip we got a email saying there had been a cancellation and we would be able to stay at the Paba our entire stay. The room was fairly small, but the bathroom was a nice size, and they were both very clean. It also included a mini fridge and a small table in the room which is where breakfast was served. The breakfast was simple but good and filling. The elevator was very old and a little scary, but always worked well. The location of the hotel was perfect. It is very close to the colesseum, and the forum, and we walked almost everywhere except the Vatican. The staff was very helpfull with directions and helping us find stamps and internet access.

Reviews.Title: “Clean and cheap, but not rated 5”
Reviews.Author: YoPhilly
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed for two nights at the Paba, based on TripAdvisor reviews, and I must say I'm surprised at the number of people who rate it a 5. Without a doubt, it is spotlessly clean and a great bargain in expensive Rome when the USD is tanking against the euro. Fabiola was very pleasant and helpful. Our room was #7 called Director's Cove and it was about 8' x 10', very small with no place to stack our luggage. In fact, we had to pile them on top of the mini-refrigerator, making it very difficult to get organized. The shower stall was so small I couldn't bend over to wash my feet; I had to open the glass door to bend down. Breakfast was adequate: juice, cappuccino, yogurt, a tiny packaged wedge of cheese and a cornetto. The location is outstanding. We walked out the door and were at the Forum within three minutes. If you stay here and are interested in buying foodie things as souvenirs, walk UP Via Cavour about 2 blocks to the Elite Supermarket. They have a wonderful selection of torrone, candies, etc. I bought three bottles of wine here to bring onboard my cruise. Good value. Directly across the street is a convenient post office as well as a small deli-style store that serves a dozen varieties of pizza. Do try the potato pizza - super-thin slices of potato with a touch of rosemary on a thin crust pizza - molto buono! I have no complaints with the Paba, other than the room size. However, it does not rate a 5.

Reviews.Title: “The perfect location”
Reviews.Author: Jeaniusann
Reviews.Content: My husband, our friend and I stayed 3 nights at the Hotel Paba, found in Rick Steve's guidebook, Italy 2007. Upon arrival, we discovered only one room reserved for us, when the confirming e- mail clearly stated we would have one double and a single. Since the hotel was fully booked, the young English-speaking receptionist, Fabiola, was distraught but her associate (and mom), Pina, relayed that she would see what she could do. Pina found us accommodations at another hotel, but near the train station and at a higher rate. Because of the ideal location of Hotel Paba, we declined the alternative and made do with the single room with a king bed and single roll-away. It was clearly a communication error. Our room was next to the reception desk. Though we were not able to hook up my husband's laptop computer, Fabiola gave him the hotel's laptop to use to download our boarding passes for our flight home. She also told us what bars/restaurants to avoid and recommended 2 wonderful places to dine just blocks away that did not disappoint. Fabiola and Pina could not have been any more accommodating. Being only blocks from the Colliseum and the main bus stop, this is an ideal place to rest your bones. Pina showed us where to get our coffee, juice and yogurt in the little closet off the lobby early the next morning and arranged for a driver to pick us up at 4am for our 6am flight home. We will definitely return to Hotel Paba.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, great place”
Reviews.Author: K-tel12
Reviews.Content: After researching Rome hotels for 6 hours online (no lie), I decided on Hotel Paba. I wanted a great location, without spending more than necessary for a place with decent amenities. Hotel Paba was recommended in Rick Steves' Italy guidebook, and well received here on Trip Advisor also. I made the right choice. The location is fantastic, even closer to the Colosseum than it appears on maps. The room has a desk, a large wardrobe, a table with two chairs. The huge bed might be a tad too stiff for some, but I didn't mind. My boyfriend and I were assigned room 2, affectionately dubbed "Lover's Nest" on the door, ha ha. Movies of bad American movies (printed in Italian) decorate the walls, which lends a homey feel. There's a stocked mini fridge, but room to put in your own drinks. There's a radio and a small TV (essential for watching "Quincy" and "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" in Italian). The bathroom is completely modern, stocked with tissues and a hair dryer (not very powerful, but it works). One of the things I enjoyed most was having breakfast in the room. Alberta will bring you breakfast each morning on a little tray. Just ring her up and two minutes later, she's at your door with fresh croissants from the nearby bakery, yogurt, bread, cheese, cookies and jam, and whatever kind of coffee or tea you like. I liked not having to search for breakfast and saving time by eating right in the room before leaving for the day. Alberta is a great hostess. She was extremeley helpful in calling cabs for us (they arrive in 3 minutes - amazing) and warning us about crooked cabbies trying to overcharge unsuspecting tourists. We were there when daylight savings time ended, and she left notes on our door reminding us to reset our clocks to the new time. Very nice! Also, the carry-out pizza joint across the street was great - some of the best pizza I had. And pretty cheap. One piece of advice: If you plan to pay with cash (for a discount), make sure you find a working ATM in advance. The night we wanted to pay for the room, both ATMs near the hotel were out of order, and we didn't have time to find another one. So the lesson is, when you see a working ATM in Rome, use it. Don't wait. A great hotel and would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Great stay at Hotel Paba”
Reviews.Author: Mtn-Biker-in-STL
Reviews.Content: My wife and I kicked off our first visit to Italy by staying at Hotel Paba in Rome (Sept. 9th - 13th). I ended up choosing this hotel based on the reviews here (and on Venere) and because of its central location. Alberta was a great hostess and helped us out several times during our stay. From restaurant recommendations to booking the Borghese tour for us, she was a valuable part of our stay! Our room itself was nice as well. We were on the Via Cavour side (a very busy street during the day and evening), but the updated windows helped keep out the noise. (After walking around Rome each day, we were so tired each night I don't even think bombs exploding outside on the street would have kept us awake!) Our little balcony was nice, too! The beds seemed typical for Europe (Alberta helped out by supplying us with a foam pad for my wife's sore joints). The room was spacious and kept very clean. The bathroom was largae and was cleaned every day as well. Overall, we were very pleased with the room. Hotel Paba is a great hotel if you are trying to travel on a budget in Rome (which is hard to do!). The location lends itself well to walking and taking the public transportation. Alberta is a great hostess and runs a fine little establishment! We will definitely return when we visit Rome again!

Reviews.Title: “Great location poor breakfast”
Reviews.Author: BENJI7
Reviews.Content: Whilst I agree that the location of the Hotel was perfect and the rooms clean & tidy I cannot agree with the comments about breakfast. I have never had to eat my meal from a serviette as there were no plates provided and the tea was served in cardboard beakers with Nescafe written on. We had the same every morning 3 very small rolls a yoghurt each, croissant jam & cheese triangle. We feel plates & cups would have made a big difference we paid 140 euros per night! We had room 2 and every night we had to put up with the noise from the cafe next door, bottles being loaded and dishes being washed. The first night this was still going on at 4.30 in the morning, luckily I had taken ear plugs! It is shame, as the owner was helpful & pleasant she recommended us to a superb Taverna called the Imperial offering home cooked food with a specials choice each night ALdo and his sister Caludia were great and always smiling. We were only going to go the first night as it was so near to the Hotel but ended up going for all 3 nights ,

Reviews.Title: “Very nice little hotel, once I got to stay there!”
Reviews.Author: debstah
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Paba for 4 nights from September 8-12. In March, I had originally made reservations to stay from the 7th to the 12th, but about a month before my arrival in Rome, Alberta, the lovely lady who owns and runs the Paba, informed me that she made a mistake and double-booked my room. I had to stay across the hall in the Hotel Ferraro, which would cost 15 euros more (115 to 100 for the Paba) for a double/single use room. I appreciated the notice and that she made alternate accommodations for me that were so convenient to the Paba, but the Ferraro doesn't compare and even though she gave me the 15 euros in cash upon my checking out, it wasn't even worth anything close to 100 euros. So that was disappointing. When you book, just double-check the dates I suppose, to avoid something like that happening. But I think it was an anomaly and I doubt that she makes the mistake often. And the only reason it was actually a problem was because of the low quality of the other hotel. Now to the hotel itself. The location is great. It is right down the street from both the Colosseum and Forum, and any bus you could possibly need, plus the metro, are all within a 5 minute walk. Multiple supermarkets and restaurants and a travel agency and internet cafes with cheap internet are all within a minute or two walk from the hotel. I had room 7, right on the reception area and right by the door to the hotel's entrance. But the room faced away from the street, so it was quiet. I heard noise from reception once in a while, but because Alberta left around 9pm and didn't return until about 7:30am, my sleep was never disturbed. She brings you breakfast in your room anytime from 7:30am to noon; you just tell her when you want it. See the picture I posted of it. It wasn't fantastic, but it was an adequate amount of food to start the day and when I was there, everything was perfectly fresh. When I checked in, I was given a very very helpful bus map, on which she outlined several of the major sites and how to get there. This was most helpful as there are so many buses in Rome that can be confusing. Any time I had questions, she or the other woman who was sometimes there were more than happy to help, look things up for me, arrange a cab to the train station for my departure, etc. Really friendly and helpful service. The room itself was good-sized. A huge bed that was actually 2 beds pushed together, but that wasn't noticeable. There was a satin covering on the sheets, which was nice. A little marble table, with chairs, for breakfast, a closet, a minibar/fridge, plenty of light, plenty of electrical outlets, and I found the bed to be comfortable, but yes as other reviews have said, it is firm. But I didn't find it so hard that it was a problem. There was a small TV up on the wall, which got a lot of stations but only BBC World in English. The bathroom was adequate with a separate shower and big sink. Everything was perfectly clean and in good condition. The air conditioning was powerful and remote-controlled. There is no internet service at the hotel. Alberta offered to let me borrow her laptop if I needed it, which was a nice gesture, but she would not give out the password for her wireless so I could use my own laptop. But the proximity of several internet cafes made it bearable if you are like me and need to check the email every day. All in all, this is a very good hotel and was worth the 100 euros. The mixup with my reservation was unfortunate because that hotel was nowhere near the class that the Hotel Paba is. But Alberta is a wonderful lady and she runs a nice little establishment. It is not without its quirks, but Rome is an expensive, hectic city, so it was nice to have a comfortable, friendly, relaxing, decently-priced place to return to at night and if I needed to rest my feet in the afternoon. If I return to Rome, I wouldn't hesitate to stay at Hotel Paba again - I'd just book really really early and I would triple-check the reservation!

Reviews.Title: “Stale breakfast every day”
Reviews.Author: Aroney
Reviews.Content: The position was really good as it was close to the forum and other tourist sites, the lift was an amazing piece of work, something out of a Hollywood movie ,My main complaint was the awful stale breakfast that we had to endure every morning with the same lame excuse being that the bakers were not operating today!! In the end I could not eat breakfast at all as it was so bad.I am sure there are better places to stay.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel Paba is great”
Reviews.Author: Jackson507
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Hotel Paba the last week of July. We booked thru the hotels website after reading favorable reviews. We were not disappointed. Rome is an expensive city and we were trying to be as conservative as possible. Hotel Paba was a great value. It was about a 15-20 minute walk from the train terminal. We stayed in room number 2 for 3 days, which was roomy and very clean and quiet. On our return visit we stayed in another room whose number I forget, it was smaller, but still spotless. Both bathrooms were smaller than we are used to, but functional, and again very clean. Both of the rooms were very quiet. The rooms are air-conditioned which was fantastic since the temperture was in the mid 90's the entire time we were there. Breakfast was adequate and served in the room. Alberta the owner was extremely helpful and courteous. She arranged early cab rides to the airport and helped with a Vatican tour. The hotel is right around the corner from the Colosseum and Forum. It is a 20 minute walk to the Pantheon and Piazza Navona. 35 minute walk to to Vatican, Spanish Steps and Trevi Fountain. We would stay at Hotel Paba again.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Hotel in the heat of Rome”
Reviews.Author: Davers01
Reviews.Content: If you're looking for a top class value for money Hotel in Rome then look no further. Hotel Paba has big sized rooms, is very well located, and most of all is the most helpful place I've ever stayed. As you'll see from many of the other reviews, the Hotel is run by Sra. Alberta who is a charming and extremely helpful lady who made our stay so very easy and pleasant. So here's some hopefully helpful info to help you if you decide to stay here: GETTING THERE: From Termini Railway Station Hotel Paba is just a 10 minute walk away. Or you can go on the metro if you want. WALKING: Exit Termini at the main doors into Cinquecento Square. Now head to your left and you're looking for a road that goes off to the left from the square called Via Cavour. We looked for the most obvious one and it was that one. Get onto that road and stay on the left hand side. Now start walking and keep going until you reach Cavour Metro Station. Here the road now does a weird thing as it kind of turns into another road (or so it seems). Nevertheless, keep on going staying to the left hand side of the road which means you'll have to cross over and once you see the Post Office across the road then look out for the hotel. METRO: Get down onto LineB (I think) and you're heading south. Cavour is the first stop. The Metro is mega easy. You just need a 1 euro coin per person and you buy a single ticket per journey. Whether you're going 1 stop or 50 with 4 changes, it's still 1 euro. You just have to use them within 75 minutes or so of them getting stamped at the gate thingy. GETTING IN: OK, so you're here now. First off - ignore the grafitti. This is Rome. Everywhere is covered in the stuff. That's Romans for you. It doesn't mean that you've walked into the heart of the Italian equivalent of Harlem. In fact you are currently only about 100 yards away from the Colisseum (turn around and go back up the street 30 yards - look down that street to your right. See that bloody great big thing down there? Yes , there - the one with the arches, yes that's it). So ring the buzzer and the door will open for you. You're heading for the first floor (one floor up - it's different for Americans isn't it). But hey - what's that groovy thing looking like something out of 'From Russia with Love?' - it's a lift that's what. Check that baby out - it's straight out of the 30's - get to know it - you're going to become friends. So you've arrived. Shut the door to the lift (both of them or others can't call the lift and the whole lift service grinds to a halt) and the main entrance to Hotel Paba is right there on your right. Step in and you will probably meet Sra. Alberta. SIG.RA ALBERTA: Now I don't know what impression you may have got from other reviews, but I must admit I was expecting someone a bit like Kim and Aggie from TV (Sorry Americans you won't get that reference). Someone who's very much in charge etc. Well she isn't at all like that. She is a wonderfully elegant lady who is genuinely pleased to meet you (and that doesn't happen often in my life I can tell you). She speaks excellent English so don't worry about any language issues, and she is a fountain of knowledge on all things Rome. Take your guidebook by all means, but if you really want to know how to get into the Vatican Museums without having to queue for hours then she's the woman in the know. THE HOTEL ITSELF: First of all - it's tidy. Very clean and very tidy. The ceilings are very high and there is a touch of Rome everywhere. The Hotel is set all on the one floor with the Reception being the central hub by the main door into the Stairwell and that groovy lift I mentioned earlier. Sra Alberta tends to hide herself away behind the reception desk watching telly so is always at hand should you need her but not in your face. There are some books available if you've forgotton to pack one and also in reception there are the standard leaflets. Sra Alberta will also hand you a free map of Rome when you check in (and it'll end up being the one you use rather than the one in the back of that very heavy DK guidebook you've bought - you did buy it didn't you - does it feel heavy yet? Have no fear.. It will) ROOMS: We only stayed in one but did manage a peak at a couple of others whilst the cleaning was being done and the first thing of note is that for a capital city the rooms are very big. The beds are also 'oversized' which in reality means 'bloody big'. Each room has Air conditioning which can be a bit loud - but it was 35 degrees outside so who's conmplaining? Our room was en-suite with a decent shower which had adequate power and there was no problem with hot water. There is a safe in the room, as well as the standard drawers and wardrobe. We also had a table and two chairs where we ate breakfast each morning. Overall the rooms are, like the rest of the hotel, tidy and spacious. BARS: So you've arrived, you've found the hotel, you've checked in, and now you want to check out the area around the hotel. This, of course, means going for a glass of wine or a beer or two. Good thinking! Head out of the Hotel and take a left down the hill towards the Forum. Go past the restaurant which has overspilt onto the road and keep going until you come across an ice cream shop / sandwich shop / bar. It's on a corner. Look - don't the people look friendly in there. All smiles. All Happy. Do you know why? It's because they charge 7 Euro's for 400ml of beer that's why. DO NOT GO IN HERE!! Carry on past until the pavement opens out a bit and there are some seating areas under umbrellas. You should be near 'The Richmond'. Go and sit in one of these. They look more expensive - but they're not. The Chianti is pretty good. We also ate here and the food was pretty decent albeit touristy. RESTAURANTS: There are loads of restaurants near to the Hotel but one which we really enjoyed and was cheap can be found if you leave the hotel and go down the hill and then look for the first (or second) left which goes back up hill (towards Colisseum). There is a restaurant on that road on the right - go past that one and there is a lovely little trattoria further up the hill on the left. It's really authentic. SUPERMARKETS: If you're anything like us then you'll want to make some sandwiches to have with you during your trecks around Rome and Hotel Paba is really well situated for that. Directly across the road is a shop which sells Bread, Meat and Cheese and also some pre made sandwiches. They're cheap and delicious. Further down the hill but on the same side as this shop is the nearest grocery / deli - you can get all sorts in here including cans of beer. OTHER SERVICES: There is also a Post Office across the road from the Hotel and bank machines and a Bureau de Change. The Bureau de Change had the best rates we found in Rome so it's worth checking out. FURTHER AFIELD: I won't bore you with any recommendations about what to do in Rome as if you don't find out for yourself then don't bother going. Well I say that, but I will recommend one thing which you really ought to do. There is an area of Rome called Travestere which you really ought to go to for an evening. You can catch the bus from outside the Hotel (ask Sra Alberta - she knows all the timetables of course). Once you get there you'll discover street upon street of bars and restaurants. Each one tucked away and then opening out into hidden little piazas. The atmosphere is lively and the prices are cheap. As you approach the river you'll come across street vendors and riverside bars. It really is a great night out and is much better than hanging around near the Forum. So that's the end of my 'TripAdvice'. I hope you found it useful. I wouldn't ever normally write something like this unless I had been very impressed with my stay - and the Hotel Paba really deserves a great write up. We found the Hotel on TripAdvisor so it seems fitting that we should add our own review and hopefully help you out as well. Enjoy your stay in Rome. It really is a wonderful city.

Reviews.Title: “Best find in Rome!”
Reviews.Author: tmstz
Reviews.Content: Booked this hotel after reading a few good reviews in Rick Steves and an Eyewitness Guide. Our stay was great as the owner of the hotel is there most of the time and is very polite and helpful and she speaks English! The hotel is close by to the Colosseum (and the Shamrock Pub!). The hotel has 8 rooms and while our room faced the street, the thick windows kept most of noisy Rome out of the room. If I go back to Rome, I will definately stay here again!

Reviews.Title: “Perfect Hotel, Perfect Hostess”
Reviews.Author: maddyd51
Reviews.Content: We booked the Hotel Paba based on a review in Rick Steves' Guidebook. We wanted a retreat from the craziness of Rome and definitely got it. Alberta was just a gem and a great source of knowledge. With only nine rooms, you get personal attention from her. The hotel is located on a busy street, but our room was still quiet despite having a window on that street. It was easy to shut out all the noise since there were two curtains, a window, and shutters. It is steps from the Forum and Colosseum and located in a neighborhood that felt safe even at night. We walked everywhere in Rome from there, even to the Vatican (about 25 minutes) and to Piazza del Popolo (about 25 minutes). It was a great way to see the city. Our room (number 4, with a sign that said "Honey Moon" on it), felt spacious, with a huge bed, large closet, dresser, and table with two chairs. There was a safe that was easy to use and the bathroom was spotless. In fact, the whole place was spotless. Alberta delivers breakfast to your room every morning. There was so much food that we'd take a few items with us to snack on throughout the day, which helped save time. There were rolls, a croissant, yogurt, and biscotti. Alberta also makes you an espresso from her espresso machine. We were checking out very early on our last day and she made up our tray for us and showed us how to use the coffee machine so we could help ourselves in the morning. I felt like this hotel was a great value, since it felt like a three star, but you got a two star price. The hug and "Ciao" I got from Alberta on our last night is one of the little moments I remember fondly from our trip.

Reviews.Title: “PABA gets thumbs-up for Rome accomodations”
Reviews.Author: 44Boppa
Reviews.Content: It was our first time in Rome, at the peak of the tourist season, and we had little tolerance for any major mistakes. We hit the nail on the head booking three nights at Hotel Paba. It's near the Colliseum and the Pantheon. Though it's on a major street (easy for cabbies to find) we had a very quiet back room. The room was bigger than we expected, quite ample for our needs. A simple breakfast of juice, rolls, yogurt, coffee and tea was available every morning at the time of our choosing. It was served by Alberta, the manager, who was unfailingly cheerful, friendly and helpful during our visit. I easily arranged the stay with her via email, and she was very responsive. Before we left home, I discovered a friend would be in Rome on the first day of our visit. I asked Alberta to recommend a restaurant nearby and make a reservation. She did so, and it worked out fine. She directed us to useful shops and services nearby and arranged for economical transportation to the airport for our departure. I don't know if we will return to Rome. But if we do I know where we will stay. Hotel PABA.

Reviews.Title: “Gem of a hotel...”
Reviews.Author: cymry
Reviews.Content: this little hotel doesn't look like much, but if you're willing to forgo looks, it's a wonderful place. the building is on a major street, but our room faced a small (shabby) courtyard, so it was very quiet. the building is old, the lobby tiny, and the rooms are very cramped, but each has its own small table and chairs where the owner brings you breakfast every morning. everything is scrupulously clean, and the help is very friendly and eager to please. best of all, if you're exploring Rome, you're at the very heart of the city! the Colosseum is a 2 minute walk away, with the Forums, Museo Capitolini, and any major attractions within easy walking distance. we didn't take the metro once - it's a 10 minute walk from Termini and, provided you're willing to explore, an easy trek from any point in the city, including the Vatican, Piazza di Spagna, etc. i'd definately stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Small Hotel”
Reviews.Author: AnnKJ
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Hotel Paba for 5 nights in June 2007. We highly recommend the hotel if one would like an immaculately clean, well maintained room in an ideal tourist location at a fair price. Our room (Skipper’s Room) was a good size, had a self-controlled air conditioner, and a comfortable queen sized bed. The bathroom and shower are a little small but immaculately clean. There is an elevator to the hotel on the third floor…..but if you prefer a workout carrying suitcases up – the stairs welcome you :). The continental breakfast (croissants, rolls, soft cheese triangles, yogurt, jellies, cappuccino, milk, hot chocolate, etc.) is served on the table in ones room. The owner, Alberta is extremely knowledgeable and helpful with Rome, busses, schedules, and she is very nice, etc. In addition, some tourist notes: -Location: A few blocks from the Colosseum and Forum. Walking distances to many major attractions. -Transportation: A bus stop in front of the hotel and other busses and the metro are a 5-minute walk. -There is a small grocery store on the corner; an outstanding gelato shop on the street; and a great souvenir/T-shirt shop is down the block. The souvenir shop is ITA INDIA, at Via Cavour – 308, and had the lowest prices my wife found in ITALY. -We would recommend avoiding the grocery store (Pizza & Mortadello) directly across the street from the hotel. They doubled the prices when they realized we were tourists…so we did not go back. The grocery store on the corner (La Voglia Di), which Alberta recommended, always treated us fairly and had lower prices. We would definitely stay at Hotel Paba in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel Paba is okay”
Reviews.Author: tagretchen
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Hotel Paba for three nights in May. The room was small, but average for Italy standards. Our room was relatively quiet. but did not face Via Cavour. Breakfast was served in the room. The location was very convenient. The hotel was only a short walk to the Colesseum and Forum, and public transportation.

Reviews.Title: “great hotel”
Reviews.Author: jagged
Reviews.Content: the hotel is in a great location, right around the corner from the Colosseum...it's on the second floor of the building it's in, but they do have a lift so you won't need to deal with luggage and stairs the hotel is on a pretty busy street and we had a room facing that street, but the windows were thick enough to keep the noise out...plus the room has A/C so there's no need to have the window open unless you want to look out it there is a store across the street that had excellent pizza, as well as beer, wine, snacks, etc...there is also a pastry shop down the street that we had breakfast at every morning that we were in Rome the room is typical of Europe in that it's small by American standards, but it was plenty of room for us...the bed was very firm, so if that is a problem for you, beware...the shower has good water pressure we were very happy with the Hotel Paba and would definitely stay there again

Reviews.Title: “Hotel Paba May 8-10”
Reviews.Author: Ladyleah
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Hotel Paba for 3 nights at the begining of our May, '07 trip to Italy which included 4 hotels. Here are the pros and cons- Pros- *Signora Alberta was simply lovely. She was very helpful and accomodating, and appears to go out of her way to do things for her guests. It's nice to deal with the owner directly. *Location. Its a great location where you can walk anywhere (although we took a cab to the Vatican) and we always felt quite safe. An reasonable walk to all of ancient Rome, the Pantheon, Piazza Navona, and the Spanish Steps. The neighborhood around the hotel was actually really great and fun of little gems like the Charity Cafe Jazz Club and a great Enoteca (wine bar) *The price was right- 145 euros per night with a 5% discount for cash payment. During high season in Rome, this is a great price. Cons- *Our room was on the Via Cavour side and it was SO noisy at night due to a bar outside the hotel that didn't get hopping until midnight. Even with earplugs the noise was a bit much. I am certain that Alberta would have moved us if the hotel was not entirely full though.... but it was. *The bed, although large, was hard as heck as people had mentioned before. I can deal with firm- but this was close to feeling like a rock! :) *The bathroom (at least in our room the "Honey Moon" room) smelled quite moldy and needed a deep clean. If we didn't leave the bathroom door closed when we left the room smelled like a bit of a gym locker room which was gross. All in all, a reasonable stay!

Reviews.Title: “A warm welcome in Rome”
Reviews.Author: traveldancer
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Hotel Paba four nights at the end of our vacation. Our owner-proprietor Alberta is everything all the reviews said---wonderful!!! She booked a ride for us to the airport at 5:30 am the day we left, and left us breakfast so we would have something that early. Some of the early reviews talked of a small breakfast---not anymore. We had croissant, cappuccino, small rolls, three small cheeses, juice, yogurt, proscuitto, packaged bread. I had asked about eggs since I can't eat sweets or bread, and she was able to help with this with hard-boiled eggs. Her information about where to go in Rome was very helpful and being able to walk to the Forum in five minutes was amazing. This was the end of our trip so having an English-speaking hostess helped our brains tired from 18 days of travel. I felt like I was at my German mother-in-law's house---you could eat off the floor of our whole bedroom and bathroom. The deli across the street was helpful and lots of restaurants were close. We would stay here again for such a lovely hostess.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful hospitality”
Reviews.Author: triciat13
Reviews.Content: My friends and I stayed here for 5 nights from 18-23 April, 2007. I had read the excellent reviews so contacted the hotel owner directly to book accommodation. We could not have found a better place to stay. The welcome was lovely, as was the hotel and, of course, the owner, Signora Alberta Castelli. It was ideal for being within walking distance of many of the famous landmarks. The only time we needed transport was to go to the Vatican. I heartily reccommend this hotel to anyone. I would also reccommend the restaurant next door the this hotel. After a couple of disappointing meals elsewhere we decided to eat at Bar Argentina. The meals were excellent, especially the Fillet Steak Argentina. Absolutely wonderful! All-in-all, we had a wonderful stay in Rome.

Reviews.Title: “Forza Paba”
Reviews.Author: JammieDodger
Reviews.Content: This is a lovely little hotel, and it's hard to believe that it's possible to get better value in Rome. Alberta is an excellent host. Very helpful and considerate. My wife and I were travelling with our son, and we booked a triple room. Except it was better than that, the third bed was in a small room adjacent to the main room. We all therefore enjoyed unexpected privacy when needed. We were delighted when we realised what our accommodation consisted of. The location of the hotel is almost perfect. It was great to step put and see the Colosseum within minutes. The Forum is seconds away also, which is great, because you can get there early to avoid the crowds, and believe me, you will want to avoid the crowds! Don't miss the Capitoline Museums, they are superb, and are also only minutes away. Museo Borghese is a 'must see' as well. Not see easy to get to from via Cavour - catch the metro from the Colosseum to Flaminio and walk from there. If you are on a bit of a budget, there is a great Pizzaria in the lane parallel to via Cavour, via Madonna di Monti. It's called Alle Callette. It seems popular with locals, the staff are friendly, and has a great buzz. If you are like me, I really enjoy eating somewhere that I can't hear the english language. That way you feel like you are away. Anyway, Pizzas from 6 euros and a bottle of Chiati for 8 euros can't be bad.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Location, Great Service”
Reviews.Author: A-square
Reviews.Content: Ms. Alberta, the owner, is a very warm person. We were given the Lover's Nest room for our honeymoon. She also gave us a map and bus services handout which turned out to be very useful. Room is big, water pressure is good, location is very close to Colloseum/Roman Forum and within walking distance to shopping area on the Via Nazionale road. Plenty of restaurants nearby. Ask for recommendation from Alberta. Last time we gave her a restaurant name card and she intends to go there to try herself. So, her recommendation is guaranteed to be of a good standard. Breakfast is good, served in the room because there's no dining area. If going there by public transportation from the train station, better take bus rather than the Metro because you'd need to go up/dpwn the stairs/escalator with your luggage in the Metro and then you also need to walk to the hotel. There is a bus with only 3/4 stops and the stop is only 2 min to the hotel (metro stop is farther). We took Ryan Air-budget airline from Rome to Venice. From the train station, there's a bus 6 Euro/person going to the budget terminal. Ticket sold in Tabachi (newstand). Location of bus departure was difficult to find, though. Be sure to ask for clear direction when using the service. But the trip was quite entertaining because we went through Rome suburban roads for about 40 min with a driver driving the big bus like driving a small car and there's some local music, too.

Reviews.Title: “Bijou hotel lets you concentrate on your Roman holiday”
Reviews.Author: JohnnyBoyLondon
Reviews.Content: Small, comfortable and friendly hotel on 2nd floor of a block on a fairly busy (traffic) street. However, shutters and double-glazed windows do ensure a good night's sleep. Excellent location: Colosseum 5mins walking and: Imperial Forums 5mins; Trajan's column 10mins; Trevi Fountain and main shopping area 20mins. [There's (a post office and) a shop selling good examples of Italian charcuterie, wine, pasta and cheese across the road, so you don't need to load yourself down with foodie souvenirs when in the city centre.] There's no breakfast room, but breakfast (including fresh bread roll and croissant) is brought speedily to your room on a tray when requested, so rapid morning departure to see the city's sights is possible. Alberta excels at attention to detail and she is very helpful. Her English is excellent, but do take the opportunity to practise some Italian! Highly recommended

Reviews.Title: “Charming and comfortable”
Reviews.Author: CanadianTraveler
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a great seven night stay at the Hotel Paba. As many people have noted, the owner Alberta Castelli is friendly and helpful. We were given a choice of two rooms so we chose a room at the front--the Imperial Suite--there was noise from the street but we wanted the balcony with a view of the ruins. The breakfast was delicious--a fresh cornetto, sweet bun, cheese, yogurt, biscuits and cappucino. By European standards the room was large and the bathroom was nice and clean--no problems with water pressure. I was concerned about the location but we walked everywhere--only took the subway twice, once to the Vatican and once to the Gallery Borgese. For 88 euros/night I thought this hotel was completely charming and a tremendous value. I would definitely stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “The bed was so large!”
Reviews.Author: ValGee
Reviews.Content: The beds at Hotel Paba are enormous but rather firm. The room was kept clean and neat. The rooms at the front of the hotel that look out onto Via Cavour are rather noisy until early morning but not as bad as some. Opening the shuttered windows in the morning is an experience too as it is a great feeling to see others making their daily deliveries and setting up shop for the day while you, being on holiday, have the time to sit and watch.The breakfasts were the same everyday and pre packaged but adequate. What made our stay at Hotel Paba so memorable was Alberta's welcoming smile when we arrived and everytime we returned. She was patient with our tirade of questions and if she did not know the answer immediately, would always do some research and give us an answer later. Alberta made us feel special! The hotel is well situated close to many of the great Roman historic sites and there are many good restaurants close by. We felt safe walking around the area during the day and at night. A waiter in a restaurant across the street from Hotel Paba initially tried to overcharge us for our meal but when we asked for the bill to be itemised, we were charged correctly. The gellatos were delicious, especially recommend the pistachio, lemon sorbet and chocolate.

Reviews.Title: “When in Rome, Stay Here”
Reviews.Author: NJTraveler79
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for several nights in December and were very pleased. I believe we were upgraded to a larger room than we had originally booked, and we were not charged any extra. The cost is very reasonable, especially given the good location (the Coloseum is literally within site). The main asset is the owner, Alberta, who was very friendly and helpful. She gave us several good dining selections, provided us with helpful site-seeing tips, and reserved tickets for our visit to the Borghese. As other reviewers have stated, breakfast is basic, but enough to get you started for a day of site-seeing. The only complaint I would have was that we stayed in a room which bordered the main street which could be very noisy even late at night, so if you are a light sleeper, try and get a room further from the street. I would definitely recommend staying here.

Reviews.Title: “lovely hotel”
Reviews.Author: jenswa
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for three nights in September in the room called "lovers nest", it was lovely and clean with a huge bed and wooden floor. Alberta the owner is a lovely lady and very helpful. The hotel is in an excellent location and we would love to stay there again if we return to rome.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel!”
Reviews.Author: cbeggs
Reviews.Content: This hotel is quite a find. It is located right on Via Cavour in Rome, very close to the Coliseum and Forum. We loved the location for starters as it is easy to get to and from the train station either via taxi or via subway (1 stop). There are plenty of good places to eat in the neighborhood as well. The owner is very pleasant and helpful. She recommended some good local restaurants, how to book our train passes to the airport, how to get to the Appian Way and was helpful in many other aspects as well. The room was large for European hotel rooms and the bathroom was a decent size with a regular shower. We lucked out and got the family room so we had an extra room with a twin bed which made the room even larger. The breakfast was served in room each morning. Our last morning there we had to catch a plane very early so the owner was kind enough to ensure we had breakfast and helped show me how to make a cappuccino and where to get the food from the hotel pantry in the morning since she would not be there in the morning to help. This was above and beyond my expectation. She normally got there around 8am. My husband and I enjoyed our stay very much and would recommend this hotel as we had a lovely experience and the accommodations were very good.
